title: Quiz 1: Anatomy of the Reproductive System
description: Assessment of external and internal genitalia, uterine structure, and supports.

questions.question: Which structure of the external genitalia is described as a highly sensitive erectile structure situated at the anterior junction of the Labia minora?
questions.explanation: The clitoris is the female equivalent of the male penis and is a highly sensitive erectile structure found at the anterior junction of the labia minora.
questions.hint: It is located above the urethral meatus.

questions.question: Match the uterine ligament with its primary function or location:

pairs.right: Provides lateral stability to the cervix
Passes backwards from cervix to sacrum
Fold of peritoneum, does not support uterus

questions.explanation: Cardinal ligaments are the main support; Round ligaments maintain anteversion; Utero-sacral ligaments pull back towards the sacrum; Broad ligaments are merely peritoneal drapes.
questions.hint: Think about which one actually holds the weight versus which one maintains the angle.

questions.question: Arrange the parts of the Fallopian Tube from the Uterus outwards to the Ovary:
questions.explanation: The order from the uterus is: Interstitial (in the wall) -> Isthmus (narrow) -> Ampulla (wide) -> Infundibulum (fimbriated end).
questions.hint: It starts inside the uterine wall and ends with the fimbriae.

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding the layers of the uterus are CORRECT? (Select all that apply)

options.text: The endometrium is the inner lining that changes during the menstrual cycle.
The myometrium consists of a single layer of longitudinal muscle.
The perimetrium is a double serous membrane extension of the peritoneum.
The basal layer of the endometrium is shed every month.

questions.explanation: The myometrium has three layers (not one), and the basal layer of the endometrium remains to regenerate the functional layer; it is not shed.
questions.hint: Focus on the muscle structure and the shedding process.

questions.question: The vaginal orifice is partially occluded by a membranous fold called the ___BLANK___ in girls who have not been sexually active.
questions.explanation: The hymen is the thin membrane partially shutting the introitus.
questions.hint: It is often associated with virginity in traditional contexts.

questions.question: Review the table below regarding Uterine Position. What is the specific term for the position where the uterus bends forward at the level of the internal os?

richContent.content:
PositionDescription
AnteversionLeans forward over the bladder
???Bends forward at the internal os

questions.explanation: Anteflexion is the bending of the uterus upon itself at the isthmus/internal os.
questions.hint: It sounds similar to 'flexing' a muscle.

questions.question: The ovaries are attached to the posterior surface of the broad ligament.
questions.explanation: The ovaries lie on the posterior surface of the broad ligament, supported by the ovarian and infundibulopelvic ligaments.
questions.hint: They are not enclosed within the broad ligament like the tubes.

questions.question: Analyze the description: 'Two small glands, situated on either side of the vaginal orifice, that secrete mucus.' Which glands are these?
questions.explanation: Bartholin's glands are located posterolaterally to the vaginal orifice and provide lubrication.
questions.hint: They can sometimes form cysts if blocked.

questions.question: What is the term for the upper rounded part of the uterus situated above the insertion of the fallopian tubes?
questions.explanation: The fundus is the dome-shaped top portion of the uterus.
questions.hint: It is the part palpated to determine uterine growth during pregnancy.

questions.question: Which of the following are functions of the Vagina? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Fertilization occurs in the Fallopian tube, not the vagina. The vagina serves as a passage for birth, menses, and receives sperm.
questions.hint: Think about where the sperm meets the egg vs where the baby exits.
